field.name: Abstract
field.definition: a brief, objective representation of the essential content of a book, article, speech, report, dissertation, patent, standard, or other work, presenting the main points in the same order as the original but having no independent literary value

dos.practice: This field is optional but should be completed for certain types of resources.
If a formal abstract is available, cut and paste or type it directly into this field.
Abstracts may often be found on formal landing pages about a resource.

Newsletters, notes, correspondence, comments, artifacts/physical objects, book reviews, animations, images, metadata profiles, software and sound generally do not have abstracts. Use the description field instead to describe such resources.
If no abstract is available, enter keywords in the keywords field to aid in the discovery of the resource.
If no abstract is available, consider using the description field to describe the resource.
Some resources benefit from both an abstract and a description. So consider whether a description should be added (e.g. SiPARCS presentations).

donts.practice: Do not write descriptions in this field.

otherPractice.header: Special Characters to Encode? Do This:
otherPractice.practice: All special characters like subscripts, superscripts, copyright and other symbols must be entity encoded numerically. See the numeric entity encodings.

documentation.example: The paper is about about war and peace.
